div1.head: “The Tale of a Guinea Pig,” 2nd draft, by John H. Andrus, [1942]
div1.p: 2nd draft

T h e T a l e o f a G u i n e a P i g
By John H. Andrus.

The doctor scrubbed a place on my arm with antiseptic, inser-
ted a hypodermic needle, slowly pressed the plunger and I was
richer by one cubic centimeter of blood, taken but a moment be-
fore from a vein of a fellow-soldier, Wallace Forbes. At that
time he was at the height of a pronounced case of yellow fever.
Forbes had been inoculated with the disease by the injection of
one-half cubic centimeter of blood from a case, acquired nat-
urally, that had proven fatal.

The “shot” was given me at 12:15 p.m. Jan. 25, 1901. Then I
stepped into an ambulance and was driven to Camp Lazear to await
developments. Six days later Major Walter Reed, in a letter to
the Surgeon-General of the Army, George M. Sternberg, wrote of
my case:

“ . . . I am very uneasy about the non-immune soldier
who got the same amount of blood at the same time” (as
four mosquito-made immunes - of whom more later). “He
seems to have acquired a very serious infection, his
temperature running along the 104° line now for three
days . . . Should he die I shall regret that I ever
undertook this work. The responsibility for the life
of a human being weighs upon me very heavily just at
present and I am dreadfully melancholic. Everything
is being done for him that we know how to do.”
(Extract from page 227, biography of General Sternberg.)
Who, What, Why, When, Where?

It may be in order at this point to explain why the lives of
men were jeopardized by deliberately inoculating them with such
a dread disease.

In those days yellow fever was so well up on the list of
great scourges that foreign countries, and sections of our own
country where it was epidemic, were rigidly quarantined. The
disease had invaded the United States more than 90 times. Vic-
tims were numbered in thousands and monetary loss in millions.
While New Orleans, with 41,348 deaths, had been hardest hit,
few of our southern cities escaped.

Cuba was thought to be the breeding ground where the epidem-
ics which invaded this country originated. In Havana alone,
between 1853 and 1900, there had been 35,952 yellow fever deaths.

Deaths from disease in the Army, during the Spanish-American
War - especially from typhoid fever - were alarmingly high.
Now, that it was necessary to maintain an army of occupation in
Cuba, there was additional danger from tropical diseases. This
danger was emphasized in a statement by Major Walter Reed and
Dr. James Carroll:

“During our occupation of the Island of Cuba, (July
to December, 1900), with every precaution brought into
exercise to ward off the disease, there have occurred
among the officers and men of the Army 1,575 cases of
yellow fever and 231 deaths.”

The Surgeon-General of the Army appointed a Board on Tropical
Diseases - with special emphasis on yellow fever. This Board,
composed of Major Walter Reed and Acting Assistant Surgeons,
3
(contract doctors), James Carroll, Jesse W. Lazear and Aristides
Agramonte, met at Columbia Barracks, Cuba, June 25, 1900.
The “Mosquito Theory”

While the Board was convinced that several theories were
groundless, Major Reed decided to investigate a theory originally
advanced by Dr. Carlos J. Finlay, of Havana, in 1881, that yellow
fever is transmitted by mosquito-bite. In spite of more than
100 experiments on human beings, between 1881 and 1895, Dr. Finlay
had been unable to demonstrate it so as to convince the medical
profession.

Human beings were used in the experiments for the reason that
animals, ordinarily used in such work, can not be given the dis-
ease. Major Reed and Doctors Carroll and Lazear agreed to sub-
mit themselves to inoculation. Dr. Agramonte, the Cuban member
of the Board, was believed to be immune.

While Major Reed was in the United States, on official business,
Dr. Carroll was inoculated by an infected mosquito, Aug. 27, 1900,
and had a very severe attack of yellow fever. While this was the
Board's first successful inoculation, it was not accepted as con-
clusive as Dr. Carroll had been within the epidemic zone several
times during the period of incubation.

The second case was Private William H. Dean, Troop B, Seventh
Cavalry. He was bitten by the same mosquito that had infected
Dr. Carroll, four days before, and by three other mosquitoes.
He had a very mild attack.

The third case was that of Dr. Jesse W. Lazear. It cost the
life of a highly educated young scientist on the threshold of
what promised to be a brilliant career. The official version of
Dr. Lazear's inoculation is based upon what he said after he be-
came ill. In substance it is that Sept. 13, 1900, he visited
the yellow fever hospital, at Havana, to collect blood from yel-
low fever patients for study. A mosquito settled on the back of
his hand and he deliberately allowed it to remain until it had
satisfied its hunger. (He had previously been bitten by a con-
taminated insect without after effects.) He became ill Sept. 18th.
and died Sept. 25th.

General Albert E. Truby, (retired), was a lieutenant and the
Post Surgeon at Columbia Barracks at the time Major Reed was there.
There was very evident mutual respect and esteem between the dis-
tinguished scientist and the young officer. In his forthcoming
“Memoir of Walter Reed and the Great Yellow Fever Episode”, General
Truby will reveal that several of Dr. Lazear's associates - inclu-
ding Major Reed - believed, but could not prove, that Dr. Lazear
inoculated himself by infected mosquitoes the same as he had inocu-
lated Carroll and Dean. It was thought probable that, after Dr.
Lazear became sick, he worried lest his life insurance be canceled
if it became known that he deliberately infected himself with a
fatal disease. The General presents many reasons and circumstances
to support this belief.

A tablet to Dr. Lazear's memory, in the amphitheater of Johns
Hopkins Hospital, bears this inscription:

“With more courage than the devotion of a soldier,
he risked and lost his life to show how a fearful pesti-
lence is communicated and how its ravages may be prevented.”

While immeasurably saddened by Dr. Lazear's death, the Board
decided to continue “mosquito theory” experiments and, at the
same time, to investigate an entirely different theory.

For more than a hundred years it had been the generally accep-
ted belief that yellow fever was transmitted by infected clothing,
bedding, furniture, etc. (Fomites.) This belief was so firmly
implanted that it was the custom of health and quarantine officers
to destroy or thoroughly disinfect such articles in, or from,
sections where yellow fever prevailed, whether it had been contam-
inated by contact with yellow fever sufferers or not. Was this
belief based on fact? Major Reed had to know.

There was erected, at Camp Lazear, a one-room frame building,
14 x 20 feet, It was poorly ventilated by intent and solid wood
shutters excluded germ-killing sunlight.

Three groups of men, in turn, occupied this building. The
first group 20 nights, the second group 21 nights and the third
group 20 nights. Each night they unpacked three large packing
boxes filled with sheets, pillow-slips and blankets purposely
soiled with black vomit and other highly disagreeable matter,
from contact with yellow fever patients. A new supply of con-
taminated bedding was used for each group. Their beds were made
with this soiled bedding and the rest was thoroughly shaken and
distributed around the room. Each morning the boxes were re-
packed. The men occupied a nearby tent during the day. At the
end of their ordeal each group was quarantined five days and re
turned to duty none the worse for their experience.

This experiment proved the uselessness of destroying valuable
property for fear of infection. Had it been known by
Lazear's death.
6
the people of the United States, during the last hundred years,
millions of dollars worth of property could have been saved.

(The names of those who underwent these experiments are given
on the accompanying “Roll of Honor”.)

Having proved that the disease could not be transmitted by
infected clothing, the Board proved that it could be caused, at
will, by the bite of an Aedes Aegypti mosquito twelve days after
she had fed on a yellow fever sufferer and, from then on, as
long as the mosquito lived.

It is highly probable that Dr. Finlay did not discover that
there must be a twelve-day incubation period before an infected
mosquito can transmit the disease. This may account for his
inability to demonstrate his theory in spite of more than 100
experiments.

In the work of Major Reed's Board seven American volunteers
were given yellow fever by mosquito-bite. (Nine if Drs. Carroll
and Lazear are included.) While some of the earlier attempts
were negative and several inoculations necessary to produce the
disease, the later infections produced yellow fever right on schedule.

The reason for the inoculation of seven American volunteers
by the injection of infected blood is difficult for a layman to
understand. These experiments were useful in establishing that
yellow fever is transmitted naturally by no means other than by
mosquito-bite.

They showed that the specific agent which caused the disease
is present in the blood at least during the first three days of
7
the attack. That its passage through an intermediate host - a
mosquito - although this seems to be natures method - is not
necessary to the life-cycle of the virus.

Blood-inoculation showed that the disease is caused by a virus
in that it cannot be seen by microscope or grown as a culture.
That the infecting agent is too minute to be seen by the micro-
scope was determined by infecting two of the volunteers with
blood which had been filtered through a bacteria-proof filter.

When I was inoculated by the injection of yellow-fever-infected
blood, the same quantity of the same blood was injected into four
of those who had recovered from yellow fever caused by mosquito-
inoculation. The fact that I, a non-immune, contracted the dis-
ease while the mosquito-made immunes did not was conclusive
evidence that my illness was true yellow fever and not malaria or
some other disease in which many symptoms are the same.

Incidentally, every diagnosis after Dec. 1, 1900, was made by
experts independent of Major Reed's Board. Usually by the Board
of Yellow Fever Experts of the City of Havana - Doctors Juan
Guiteras, Carlos J. Finlay, A Diaz Albertini and Major W. C.
Gorgas.
A special reason for my inoculation will appear later.

p.hi: I am Detailed With the Board

div1.p:
Early in October, 1900, the Post Surgeon, Lieut. Truby, had
me detailed for duty with Major Reed's Board to replace a man
brought from the Major's laboratory, in Washington, whose en-
listment had expired.
who

Major Reed and Dr. Carroll were bacteriologists. They set
up a laboratory in one of the buildings on the grounds of the
Post Hospital at Columbia Barracks. Both spent a great deal of
8
time at microscopes in a vain effort to find the micro-organism
responsible for yellow fever. Most of my work was in this labor-
atory where I had hundreds of captive mosquitoes. Many of them
had been matured from pupae or larvae which I had obtained from
receptacles containing stagnant water. Also it was my job to
“raise” mosquitoes from eggs.

Major Reed and Dr. Carroll talked of plans for the work of the
Board and of progress as they were busy at their microscopes and
I with my “pets”. They paid no more attention to me than to the
furniture. I heard them discuss the Major's desire to have
Lieut. Albert E. Truby appointed to fill the vacancy on the Board
caused by Dr. Lazear's death. The Major had discussed this with
Lieut. Truby and he had agreed to submit to inoculation. At
that time there was such a shortage of medical officers available
that the assignment was postponed and, in the end, not made.

Both Major Reed and Dr. Carroll expressed gratitude at their
good fortune in having the services of the yellow fever specialist,
Dr. Roger Post Ames. Major Reed voiced the belief that a single
death among the volunteers would frighten others into withdrawing
and thus halt the work. On one occasion Major Reed told Dr.
Carroll that Dr. Ames' male nurse, Gust E/. Lambert, had volunteer-
ed for inoculation. Both agreed that Lambert was too valuable,
assisting Dr. Ames, to risk breaking up the combination.

Dr Ames' remarkable success is emphasized by the fact that, fol-
lowing establishment of the “mosquito theory” by Major Reed,
another board, under the leadership of Dr. Juan Guiteras, under-
took further experiments in Havana. Three deaths among seven
volunteers brought the experiments to an abrupt halt.

When Major Reed and Dr. Carroll reached the laboratory one
morning they continued a discussion that had evidently been going
on for some time. It appeared that a patient with experimental
yellow fever, (Forbes), had reached the stage where his blood
should be taken to infect the next subject and that the volunteer
they had expected to use had backed out. Major Reed insisted
that he was going to have himself inoculated. Dr. Carroll
pleaded with him to change his mind, pointing out that the Major's
age was against him and that a recent illness had left him in no
condition to fight yellow fever. The Major said that if Dr.
Finlay's latest theory was correct he would be in no danger.
what

I got only a vague idea of the “new theory” at that time but,
later, found this explanation: In the New York Medical Record
of May 27, 1900, Dr. Finlay modified his original theory ...

“... to include the important circumstance that the
faculty of transmitting the yellow fever germ need not be
limited to the parent insect, directly contaminated
by stinging a yellow fever patient (or perhaps by con-
tact with or feeding upon his discharges), but may be
likewise inherited by the next generation of mosquitoes
issued from the contaminated parent.”

Major Reed pointed out that he had allowed several such “next
generation” mosquitoes to feed on his hands. (The hemoglobin
of the blood seems necessary for the maturation of the ova of
the female mosquito and she cannot deposit her eggs until she
has had a meal of blood.)

I had allowed a great many mosquitoes, hatched from the eggs
of infected insects, to feed on my blood. The Major and Dr.
Carroll had “fed” a few. This was to determine whether they,
in turn, would deposit eggs - whether eggs they did deposit would
hatch - and whether the new generation was normal. (Infection
with yellow fever seemed to have no effect on the insect.)

The Major said that if Dr. Finlay's new theory was correct he
would have contracted yellow fever. On the other hand, if he
was inoculated with blood and got the disease, it would indicate
that he was not a natural immune and that the modified theory was
erroneous. He admitted, when pinned down by Dr. Carroll, that
he did not think there was anything in it.

They continued to discuss the Major's proposed infection, inter-
mittently, until he left the laboratory in something of a temper
with the declaration that he would be would be inoculated “tomorrow”
and that there was no use discussing it farther.
I did some very serious thinking that night.

Next morning Dr. Carroll was first to reach the laboratory.
I asked him if I would not do as well as the Major for the inocula-
tion. He said “no” with apparent regret, pointing out that the
Major was determined to use this as a means of testing Dr. Finlay's
modified theory. I reminded him that I had “fed” many more mos-
quitoes, hatched from the eggs of infected insects, by allowing them to
take blood from my hands and wrists than the Major had. He knew
it was true.

When the Major arrived, Dr. Carroll sent me on an errand. Upon
my return, the Major asked me if I realized what I was letting
11
myself in for. I told him I had nursed yellow fever when sta-
tioned at Guanajay Barracks and had seen men die of it. He asked
why I was volunteering and seemed satisfied with my answer. I do
not know what I told him but one thing is certain, I did not tell
him that I had any idea of “saving” the Major. I knew something
of what proof of the “mosquito theory” would mean to mankind.
I knew that Major Reed was the mainspring that made the Board tick
and that if he was sick of yellow fever and had a slow recovery -
as Dr. Carroll had - the work of the Board would all but stop.
Then, too, there is something in my makeup that has always made me
willing to “die “for any” dear old Siwash” in which I became very
interested.

And here, as said in the movies, is where we came in. I had
been inoculated and was on my way to Camp Lazear - remember?
There I was assigned to a small tent, at liberty to go where I
pleased within the camp, while the “bugs” with which I had been
infected set up housekeeping and raised families in my blood stream.

One of the first things I did was to write home. I told my
mother that I had been detailed to accompany a troop of the Seventh
Cavalry on a practice march into the interior of the Island and
would not be able to write again for two or three weeks. I didn't
feel too good about this. I wanted to leave things so that the
folks at home would not worry when they did not hear from me for a
while and that was the most reasonable explanation that occurred
to me. I did not like the idea of lieing in my letter for I real-
ized that it might be the last letter I would ever write home.

Time passed slowly. I knew, from what I had heard about prev-
ious experimental cases, that there is a wide variation in the time
12
between inoculation and the chill that heralds the disease.
I don't think I worried much - certainly not enough to interfere
with my appetite. I had a bad quarter-hour, however, when I
heard that Dr. Ames was sick and, himself, in the hospital. He
had doctored all of the experimental cases and had lost but one -
Dr. Lazear.

p.hi: I Learn More About Yellow Fever

div1.p:
At 1:15 p.m., Jan. 28 - just three days and one hour after my
inoculation - the chill I had been awaiting arrived. At first
I thought my imagination was playing tricks on me for at noon my
temperature and pulse had been normal and I had enjoyed my dinner.
I finally decided that my imagination had never been quite that
vivid and suggested that my temperature be taken. The official
record says: “... At 3 p.m. temperature was 103.6°, pulse 120.

His eyes were intensely congested and the face deeply
suffused... The patient was restless and complained of
occipital headache and back ache... Skin hot and dry...
The height of the primary paroxysm was reached at 3:30
p.m...temperature 104.2°, pulse 120... The subsequence
was one of severe yellow fever. There was no remis-
sion of the fever until the fourth day... The skin of
the face and .. part of the neck was timted” (yellow)
“on the fourth day. This rapidly became intensified
and general... Secondary fever lasted 30 hours...
Marked fluctuations of temperature continued until the
eleventh day... Recovery was slow and much delayed by
the development of a carbuncle”.

These extracts show that the record was a combination of the
curtness of a soldier and the precision of a scientist. It gave
no hint of Major Reed's fear that I might die, and the resulting
melancholy, expressed in his letter to the Surgeon-General quoted
near the beginning of this article.

The “carbuncle” referred to provided opportunity for Dr/. Ames
and Lambert to demonstrate why Major Reed regarded them so highly.
When my carbuncle had reached a stage where it was tormenting me,
the doctor who was pinch hitting for Dr. Ames did nothing about it.
This worried Lambert and he went to the hospital where Dr. Ames
was sick and, waiting until his nurse was out of the room, told
him about me. Dr. Ames had Lambert and another Hospital Corps
man carry him, on his bed, to my bedside where he opened my car-
buncle.
Pinto?

From the time I left the Army, in 1902, until 27 years later,
my yellow fever experience was but an interesting memory. Then,
on Feb. 28, 1929, Congress awarded gold medals and inclusion on
an honor roll - published annually in the Army Register - to the
four members of the Board, the 14 American volunteers who had
yellow fever by inoculation and the four who underwent the infec-
ted bedding experiment but did not have yellow fever.

An annuity of $1500, for life, was awarded the 17 volunteers
then living. and to the widow of one volunteer who had died before
the bill was enacted. Annuities have not been granted to the
widows of volunteers who have died since. The widows of deceased
Board members were receiving annuities through previous legislation.
(The names which appear on the honor roll will be given later.)

Major Walter Reed died Nov. 23, 1902, only two-and-a-half
years after the first meeting of the Board. Within this brief
time he saw remarkable results in the saving of lives and prop-
erty due to the findings of his Board.

What the verdict of “guilty” against the mosquito meant is
shown by what it accomplished in the yellow fever stronghold,
Havana. From 1853 to 1900 Havana had recorded an average of
767 yellow fever deaths per year. In 1900, before the “theory”
was accepted and mosquito-extermination started, there were 1240
cases in Havana with 306 deaths. Then, in 1901, Major W. C.
Gorgas - who later became famous as Chief Sanitary Officer on
the construction of the Panama Canal - directed the extermination
of mosquitoes. In 1901 - before there had been time for exter-
mination to become fully effective - there were but 30 cases in
Havana and olly six deaths. The monthly record for the two years:

No case of yellow fever ocurred in Havana between 1901 and 1905.
In 1902 the Cuban Republic was established and, in 1905, yellow
fever again invaded Cuba due to the neglact of mosquito prevention.

In Oct., 1906, it became necessary to send American troops to
Cuba to restore order and representative government. With yellow
fever again epidemic in Cuba the lives of American soldiers were
in jeopardy. Then Major Reed's old friend, Major Jefferson R.
Kean, (whom we had known as Chief Surgeon at Mariano, in 1900),
demonstrated anew the value of his dead colleague's work. He
drove yellow fever from the Island by directing warfare against
15
the mosquito, just as Major Gorgas had done five years before.

As far as known there has been no yellow fever in Havana
since 1908.

General Leonard Wood was Governor-General of Cuba at the time
Major Reed's Board did its work there. The General was an Army
physician before he became a line officer. He fully understood
what proof of the “mosquito theory” would mean. He authorized
the inoculation of soldiers who volunteered and lent every en-
couragement, including an appropriation which made the full in-
vestigation possible.

At a memorial meeting of scientific men, in Washington,
shortly after Major Reed's death, General Wood said:

“I know no other man on this side of the world who
has done so much for humanity as Dr. Reed. His dis-
covery resulted in saving more lives annually than
were lost in the Cuban war, and saves the commercial
interests of the world greater financial loss each
year than the cost of the Cuban war.”

“He came to Cuba at a time when one-third of the
officers of my staff died of yellow fever, and we
were discouraged at the failure of our efforts to
control the disease. In the months when the disease
was ordinarily worst the disease was checked and
driven from Havana. That was the first time in
nearly 200 years that the City had been rid of it.”

“The value of his discovery cannot be apprecia-
ted by persons who are not familiar with the conditions
of tropical countries. Hereafter it will never be
16
possible for yellow fever to gain such headway that
quarantine will exist from the mouth of the Potomac
to the mouth of the Rio Grande. Future generations
will appreciate fully the value of Dr. Reed's services.
His was the originating, directing and controlling
mind in this work and the others were assistants only.”

In the 41 years since Major Reed's Board held its initial
meeting, all that Major Reed hoped and much that General Wood
predicted has come true.

I have never had a moments regret for having enacted the
role of guinea pig - on the contrary - I have always considered
it a high privilege to have been allowed a humble part in
“The Conquest of Yellow Fever”.

An act of Congress, approved Feb. 28, 1929, awarded a gold
medal and an annuity of $1500, for life, for each of the fol-
lowing and further provided: "..in special recognition of the
high public service rendered and disabilities contracted in
the interest of humanity and science as voluntary subjects
for experimentation during the yellow fever investigations in
Cuba, the Secretary of War be directed to publish annually in
the Army Register a roll of honor on which shall be carried
the following names:
M E M B E R S O F T H E B O A R D
Major WALTER REED - Chairman of the Board
Dr. JAMES CARROLL - Han experimental yellow fever
Dr. JESSE W. LAZEAR - Died of yellow fever
Dr. Aristides Agramonte - Thought to be immune

After submitting to the infected bedding experiment, without
getting the disease, Jernegan (4) was twice inoculated by mos-
quitoes but escaped infection; then inoculated by blood which
caused a sharp attack of yellow fever - the only volunteer to
take all three experiments. Folk (6) and Hanberry (10) were
inoculated by mosquitoes. Weatherwalks (16), bitten by 12
mosquitoes, was not ill. Hildebrand (17) was refused inoc--
ulation because of his age.

Names are from the official roll. Arrangement is writer's.
